title: Is it true that the Nazis hated the term “Nazi”? - Quora

response.answer_text: According to the Online Etymology Dictionary, kind of. As another answer said, it may have come from a slang term referring to ignorant Bavarian hillbillies. That made the term “Nazi” popular among its critics (who then spread it abroad) and unpopular among the Nazis. The OED simply says that the Nazis avoided calling themselves Nazis, though, not that they hated it. I couldn’t find any evidence that they passed laws the term or crushed anyone who used it, which I imagine would be their response if it really bothered them.

Nazi is just a shortened for of the party’s name (Nationalsozialist - National Socialist). It wasn’t considered (by them) to be derogatory as such. That’s not to say it was favoured as it was favoured, although the he NSDAP briefly adopted the designation "Nazi" an an attempt to avoid derogatory references by opponents. However, that rather failed and they did tend to avoid the term in any official party sense. Of course, it became increasingly used as a derogatory terms by exiles from the regime as the party came to power and then progressed through the war.
